questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) is true?

options.A: The GBM is primarily composed of collagen type I and elastin.
options.B: The GBM is a selective barrier between the glomerular capillaries and Bowman's capsule.
options.C: Thickening of the GBM is a characteristic feature of minimal change disease.
options.D: The GBM is impermeable to large molecules such as albumin.

questions.explanation: Bowman's capsule. Correct answer: B) The GBM is a selective barrier between the glomerular capillaries and Bowman's capsule. Explanation: Option B accurately describes the function of the GBM, which acts as a semipermeable barrier, allowing small molecules to pass while restricting the passage of larger molecules, such as proteins, thereby facilitating urine formation. GBM primarily comprises collagen type IV, laminins, proteoglycans, and other glycoproteins.(Option A) Thickening of the GBM is associated with conditions such as diabetic nephropathy and membranous nephropathy, but not minimal change disease, which typically shows normal or minimal changes in the GBM under light microscopy.(Option C) GBM is permeable to small molecules but is a selective barrier to larger molecules such as albumin. (Option D)

questions.question: A 60-year-old female presents with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections and lower abdominal pain. Upon physical examination, palpable masses are noted in the pelvis. Urinalysis reveals persistent pyuria. A biopsy was done on the bladder lesions, which is shown below. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for the patient's presentation?
questions.explanation: CORRECT ANSWER: B )Malakoplakia EXPLANATION: Malakoplakia: Acquired defects in phagocyte function. It arises in chronic bacterial infection, mostly by E. coli Morphology: Cystoscopically, malakoplakia takes the form of soft yellow, slightly raised mucosal plaques , 3 to 4 cm in diameter. Histologically, the lesion comprises aggregates of large foamy macrophages known as Hansmann Cells. The laminated mineralised concretions from calcium deposition in enlarged lysosomes, known as Michaelis-Gutmann bodies , are typically present within the macrophages. Bladder carcinoma typically would reveal malignant cells.( Option A) Schistosomiasis can cause chronic granulomatous inflammation in the bladder wall, leading to fibrosis and calcification.( Option C) Tubercular cystitis reveals caseating granulomas with Langhans giant cells and epithelioid cells.( Option D)

questions.question: Which of the following statements are true regarding autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease? 1) The gene associated with this condition is seen on chromosome 6. 2) The affected protein is fibrocystin. 3) It is associated with cyst formation in other organs. 4) The most common cause of death in these patients is hypertensive heart disease.
questions.explanation: CORRECT ANSWER: B )3,4 EXPLANATION: Characteristics ADPKD ARPKD Affected age group Adults Children Cysts Are present in both outer and inner surfaces Present only on the inner surface. Involved gene PKD 1 on chromosome 16 PKD 2 on chromosome 4 PKHD on chromosome 6 (Statement 2) Protein affected polycystin Fibrocystin (Statement 3) Histology Complications Coronary or hypertensive heart disease (40%). (Statement 4) Infection (25%). Ruptured berry aneurysm or hypertensive intracerebral haemorrhage (15%). Neonatal period: Respiratory failure due to pulmonary hypoplasia. Renal failure. Childhood and adolescence: Progressive renal failure leading to ESRD. Complications of CKD. Complications from hepatic fibrosis. Images

questions.question: Match the following types of renal crystals with their characteristics Types of Renal Crystals Characteristics 1. Calcium Oxalate Monohydrate A. Coffin lid-shaped crystals, commonly found in alkaline urine 2.. Uric Acid B. Rhomboid-shaped crystals, typically seen in acidic urine. 3. Cystine C. Dumbbell or ovoid-shaped crystals are often colourless in acidic urine. 4. . Struvite (Magnesium Ammonium Phosphate) D. Hexagonal plates, often associated with acidic urine
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) 1-C, 2-B, 3-D, 4-A Explanation: The microscopic appearance of various types of crystals and their descriptions are given below: Struvite/ Staghorn stones: Radioopaque. Seen in alkaline urine. Rectangular/coffin lid appearance. Associated with urea-splitting organisms. Cystine Stones Radiopaque. Seen in acidic urine. Hexagonal Shaped. Very hard stones. Calcium Oxalate Monohydrate stones Radiopaque. Seen in acidic urine. Dumbell shaped. Most common type of renal calculi. Uric Acid crystals Radiolucent. Seen in acidic urine. Rhomboids or parallelograms. Ammonium Urate crystals Radiolucent. Associated with laxative abuse.

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presents with complaints of severe lower abdominal pain, dysuria, and hematuria. She has a history of recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs). Urinalysis reveals a high pH of 8.5 and the presence of white blood cells. Microscopic examination of the urine sediment shows the following finding. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of the patient's current presentation?
questions.explanation: CORRECT ANSWER : C)Infection with urease-producing bacteria EXPLANATION: Triple phosphate stones, also known as struvite stones, are composed of magnesium ammonium phosphate. They typically form in alkaline urine due to urinary tract infections caused by urease-producing bacteria. These bacteria hydrolyse urea into ammonia, increasing urine pH and facilitating stone formation. Struvite stones are characterised by their "coffin lid" appearance under a microscope. They can grow rapidly and fill the renal pelvis, leading to complications like infection and obstruction. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, page 947

questions.question: Match the following renal casts with the conditions they are associated with: Renal Cast Type Condition Associated 1. Hyaline casts A. Nephrotic syndrome 2. Granular casts B. Chronic Renal Failure 3. Waxy casts C. Acute tubular necrosis 4. Fatty casts D. Fever
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C)1-D, 2-C, 3-B, 4-A Explanation: All casts are composed of Tamm-Horsfall protein produced in the thick ascending limb of loop of Henle . questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents with confusion, nausea, and abdominal pain after consuming antifreeze due to stress. Urinalysis reveals elevated BUN and creatinine. Microscopic examination is shown below. Identify the type of cast.
questions.explanation: CORRECT ANSWER: D)Muddy brown casts EXPLANATION: The clinical vignette of a patient with a history of anti-freeze consumption presenting with confusion, nausea, abdominal pain, elevated BUN and creatinine is suggestive of ethylene glycol poisoning . Muddy brown casts will be seen in this condition. Muddy brown casts: They are often seen in patients with ethylene glycol poisoning, leading to acute tubular necrosis (ATN). Ethylene glycol metabolites can damage renal tubules, resulting in the formation of muddy brown casts in urine sediment. . The dark brown colouration is due to haemoglobin breakdown products and other cellular components. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, page 947

questions.question: All of the following are true about medullary sponge kidney except:

options.A: It is more common in adults.
options.B: It is characterised by dilated collecting ducts in the renal medulla.
options.C: It often presents with recurrent urinary tract infections.
options.D: Cysts are lined by cuboidal epithelium.

questions.explanation: Correct answer : C)It often presents with recurrent urinary tract infections. Explanation: Medullary Sponge Kidney (MSK) often presents with recurrent urinary tract infections is incorrect because recurrent UTIs are not a defining feature of the condition . While patients with MSK may experience urinary tract infections, it is not a characteristic or common presentation of the disease. It is usually asymptomatic. Medullary Sponge Kidney: The term medullary sponge kidney is restricted to multiple cystic dilations of the collecting ducts in the medulla. The condition occurs in adults and is usually discovered radiographically. (Option A) . Renal function is usually normal. On gross inspection, the papillary ducts in the medulla are dilated (Option B) and small cysts may be present. The cysts are lined by cuboidal epithelium or occasionally by transitional epithelium. (Option D). Unless there is superimposed pyelonephritis, cortical scarring is absent. The pathogenesis is unknown. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, page: 944
